importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Hamas attack on Israel that led to the abduction of Eliyahu Margalit and the start of the Gaza war.
The date of the latest news report identifying Margalit’s remains and reporting on the ongoing hostage recovery and ceasefire process.
The day before the body identification, when Hamas handed over an 11th body that was not a hostage, signaling ongoing challenges in the ceasefire implementation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the ceasefire agreement has been in effect, and during which the handover of hostages’ remains and humanitarian aid deliveries have been central issues.
The timeframe during which the international community has been monitoring the ceasefire, including aid flows and body recoveries, with particular attention to violations and progress.

keyTakeAways: The remains of Eliyahu Margalit, a 76-year-old Israeli man abducted on October 7, 2023, were identified in Khan Younis, Gaza, after forensic testing by Israel’s National Center for Forensic Medicine.
Margalit is the 10th confirmed hostage body returned since the ceasefire went into effect; Hamas has handed over an 11th body, but it was not a hostage.

The handover of remains remains a key sticking point under the ceasefire, with Hamas insisting on full recovery of all 28 bodies, while Israel maintains control over half of Gaza and cites unexploded ordnance as a barrier.
The hostage forum, supporting families of abducted individuals, continues weekly rallies until all remaining 18 hostages are returned.
Despite the ceasefire, Hamas accuses Israel of violating the agreement by killing civilians in Gaza City, with nine deaths reported from a vehicle hit by Israeli fire.

Humanitarian aid remains severely restricted, with only 339 trucks offloaded so far, far below the 600 per day agreed upon. The famine in Gaza is confirmed by the UN, with over 400 deaths due to malnutrition, including over 100 children.
Israel claims to have allowed sufficient food, accusing Hamas of theft; aid agencies deny this, and the situation has led to a humanitarian crisis.
The ceasefire agreement includes the return of 15 Palestinian bodies by Israel to Gaza, bringing the total returned by Israel to 135 bodies.

namedEntities.name: Eliyahu Margalit
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli citizen abducted on October 7, 2023, from Kibbutz Nir Oz, whose remains were identified on October 18, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His identification marks the 10th confirmed return of a hostage body under the ceasefire and provides emotional closure to his family, yet underscores the continued struggle to recover the remaining 18 hostages.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Palestinian militant group that initiated the attack on Israel on October 7, 2023, and is now engaged in negotiations under a ceasefire agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is central to the ceasefire process, committing to return all hostage bodies and demanding more aid and border access, while also accusing Israel of violations and restricting aid flows.

namedEntities.name: Israel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Israeli state that launched a military campaign into Gaza following the Hamas attack and maintains control over half of Gaza under the ceasefire.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel is a key actor in the ceasefire, responsible for returning bodies and allowing aid, but faces criticism over civilian casualties and restrictions on humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: United States President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. political figure who warned Israel that he would allow a resumption of war if Hamas fails to return all hostage bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s conditional support adds political pressure on Hamas to fulfill its obligations, influencing the dynamics of the ceasefire and hostage recovery process.

namedEntities.name: National Center for Forensic Medicine (Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli institution that conducted the forensic identification of Eliyahu Margalit’s remains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It played a critical role in confirming the identity of the remains, providing official validation and reinforcing the legitimacy of the recovery process.

namedEntities.name: Hostage Forum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization that supports families of hostages abducted during the conflict.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It continues to advocate for the return of all remaining hostages and organizes public rallies, maintaining pressure on both sides to fulfill the ceasefire terms.

namedEntities.name: Khan Younis
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in Gaza where Margalit’s remains were found.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is a key location in the recovery process, where bulldozers excavated pits to locate remains amid rubble and unexploded ordnance.

namedEntities.name: Rafah Border Crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A crossing point between Gaza and Egypt, which Hamas is urging mediators to open for increased aid delivery.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is a focal point for humanitarian access, with ongoing demands to expedite its opening as a lifeline for Gaza’s people.

namedEntities.name: Nasser Hospital
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A facility in Gaza that received the returned Palestinian bodies from Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It serves as a central logistics hub for the handling and distribution of returned bodies under the ceasefire agreement.

namedEntities.name: Civil Defense (Hamas-run Interior Ministry)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A first-response agency in Gaza that reported civilian casualties from Israeli fire.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It documented the killing of nine people, including women and children, in a vehicle crossing into Israeli-controlled territory, raising concerns about ceasefire violations.

namedEntities.name: COGAT
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Israeli defense body overseeing humanitarian aid in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It reported on the volume of aid trucks entering Gaza, indicating the current flow of humanitarian support under the ceasefire.

namedEntities.name: United Nations
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international organization that monitors the humanitarian situation in Gaza and confirms deaths due to malnutrition.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provides data on civilian deaths, aid flows, and body recoveries, serving as a neutral source of verification during the conflict.

summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 18, 2025, Israel confirmed the identification of the remains of Eliyahu Margalit, a 76-year-old man abducted on October 7, 2023, during the Hamas-led attack on Israel. His body was found in Khan Younis, Gaza, after excavation by bulldozers. Margalit is the 10th confirmed body returned since the ceasefire agreement took effect a week prior. Hamas continues to insist on returning all 28 hostage bodies, while accusing Israel of violating the ceasefire by killing civilians, including nine in a vehicle incident in Gaza City. The hostage forum continues weekly rallies demanding the return of the remaining 18 hostages. Meanwhile, humanitarian aid remains severely restricted, with only 339 of 600 trucks offloaded since the ceasefire began, and over 400 people have died of malnutrition, including 100 children. Israel maintains control over half of Gaza and has returned 15 Palestinian bodies, bringing the total to 135. The situation remains tense, with international actors like the U.S. and UN monitoring the process and urging compliance with the ceasefire terms.
title: Israel Identifies Body of Abducted Hostage Eliyahu Margalit as Ceasefire Efforts Continue
